mentions.context: We use Librosa library [27] from Python for the feature extraction.
Besides, the UCLASS dataset was collected in a controlled environment, whereas the real-time disfluency detection is a demanding problem.
We have used the UCLASS release 1 stuttering dataset that has been created by the Department of Psychology and Language Sciences, University College London [21].
Our experiments with the UCLASS dataset show promising recognition performance.
We develop StutterNet with PyTorch library in Python [26].
We evaluate our system on the UCLASS stuttering dataset consisting of more than 100 speakers.
The method was trained on 24 speakers from the UCLASS [21] stuttering datatset, and considered spectrograms as input feature.

In order to evaluate the model performance on this UCLASS dataset, we have used the metrics including: precision, recall, F1-score and accuracy which are the standard and are widely used in the disfluent speech domain [20].
This might be due to the possible reason that the baseline StutterNet is overparameterized due to the limited size of the UCLASS dataset.

However, in this paper, we are focusing only on the core behaviors as the dataset contains only few of the remaining  In order to evaluate the StutterNet method on the UCLASS dataset, we adopted K-fold cross validation technique , where K=10.
